question_text: What do you think is the most important criterion for measuring a child’s success in life? (Pick up to 3)
What do you mean by "academic success"? (Pick up to 2)
Does your child like school?
Does your child like study?
Do you like study?
Did you like school?
What are you most worried about in your child’s future? (Pick up to 2)
Do you think governments take care of the needs of young people?
Do today’s youth have a real voice in shaping the future?
If your child couldn’t find a stable job in the future, how would you try to help? (Pick up to 2)
What do you think is the most effective way for adults to support the future of young people? (Pick up to 2)

Regular family rituals, like eating dinner together, can strengthen a sense of belonging. Especially for children, this stability contributes to a sense of psychological security.  Does your family eat dinner together?
What do you usually do at dinner? (Multiple choices possible)
What jobs does your child do in the house?
Is their allowance based on anything?
What do they usually do with their allowance?
What if your most-used phrase became your legacy?  Which of these do you say most often when talking with your child? (Check all that apply)
Which of these do you say most often about your child’s actions or choices? (Check all that apply)
When setting limits or correcting behavior, which of these do you say most often? (Check all that apply)

Every couple fights—it’s part of being close. But how you argue teaches the child something: What respect looks like. Whether people take responsibility. Whether things get repaired—or just buried.  How do you and your spouse/partner argue?
What do you and your spouse usually argue about?
What does your child do when you fight?
Support starts with knowing what’s heavy—on your shoulders and theirs.  What is weighing on you lately?
What is weighing on your child lately?
What do you wish your child understood about you?
How often does your child share concerns or worries with you?
What do you usually do when your child shares his or her troubles with you?
When your child complains about being stressed, do you say:
Have you ever said any of the following?
Do you yell at your children at home?
What if the reason they lie… is what we’re not ready to hear?  Does your teen lie to you?
How often do you think they lie?
What do you think your teen is usually hiding when they lie?
Why do you think teens might lie? (Choose all that apply)
If they told you the truth, would you know how to help them?
Does your child actively talk to you about psychological stress?
When it comes to communicating about mental health, which approach do you lean towards?
What do you do when your child refuses to communicate?
If your child showed signs of depression, how would you respond?
How would you feel before your child’s first date?
How would you feel when your child is falling in love for the first time?
If your child was ghosted, what would you want them to know about their worth and how to move forward?
What would you say to your child if they were heartbroken and didn’t feel seen or valued anymore? (Pick all that make your heart do the thing 💘)
Friendships can be a lifeline — or feel painfully absent. Does your child have friends?
Lunchtime can say a lot about belonging — and even shape a child’s mood or mental health. Who does your child usually sit with at school lunch?
Friends’ parents often give clues about the company kids keep. Do you know your child’s friends’ parents?
Hanging out can mean many things — from studying or movies to mischief. Do you know what your child does when they hang out with friends?
Being left out stings, whether you’re 14 or 40. If your child is left out of a party, what would you do?
Their phone adds a new dimension to your child’s life. What does your child use their phone for?
Do you find that they talk less with you after getting a phone?
How do you feel about your child using social media?
How do you respond to your child playing computer or video games?
When we’re on our phones, children often feel our attention shift — and that matters more than the screen itself. When you’re on your phone or computer, how do you think it affects your child?
What is your primary feeling about being a parent?
Does the reality of parenting match your imagination before becoming a parent?
What has surprised you the most about being a parent? (Pick up 2)
If you could go back, what would you tell yourself before becoming a parent? (Pick up 2)
Looking back, do you feel you were well prepared to be a parent?
What have you learned about yourself since becoming a parent? (Pick up to 4)
As a parent, do you have enough support?
What kind of support do you wish you had more of as a parent? (Pick up to 2)
Do you feel other parents have the same struggles?
When your child disappoints you, what feeling comes up first?
When parenting gets stressful, what helps you stay calm — or at least, less overwhelmed?
